<p>This is a decisive moment in the history of human health.</p>
<p>In many respects, health is a remarkable success story. Over the past century, life expectancy has dramatically increased in most parts of the world. But the portion of life we human beings spend in moderate and poor health hasnt changed, meaning we spend more years in poor health than at any point in history. Moreover, significant inequity continues to exist across and within countries.</p>
<p>We can do betterquickly.</p>
<p>Humanity mobilized against COVID-19 at a speed and scale previously unseen. While far from perfect, our success should inspire us to challenge what we think is possible. At its best, our response to COVID-19 demonstrates that when resources and motivation coalesce, scientific breakthroughs and large-scale behavior change are possible in very short periods of time.</p>
<p>Its time to set a new, more ambitious, more relevant goal for human healtha goal that galvanizes across continents, sectors, and communities to support everyone on the planet in adding years to their lives and life to their years. Humanity needs a goal that yields more time with loved ones, more accomplishments, and more time free from cognitive or physical impairment.</p>
<p>As a starting point for discussion, the McKinsey Health Institute (MHI) believes that over the next decade humanity could add as many as <strong>45 billion extra years of higher-quality liferoughly six years per person on average, and substantially more in some countries and populations.</strong><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="425db818-e9ea-4c3b-a336-b982c9d9faf1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="425db818-e9ea-4c3b-a336-b982c9d9faf1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Calculated in a scenario-based simulation sizing three effects: increase of life expectancy (extending), decrease of lifetime spent in poor health, and decrease of lifetime in moderate rather than good health (lifting and squaring the curve"). Data sources comprise WHO HALE data, health system data, life-expectancy data for more than 20,000 administrative regions globally, and the McKinsey Global Institutes Prioritizing Health report. The MHI aspiration to add 6 years of higher quality life on average is going significantly beyond delaying the average onset of disease from e.g. 55 to 65 years mentioned in the latter report.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Achieving this objective requires us, as a society, to challenge our beliefs about health and reorient material portions of public policy and the economy.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Achieving this objective requires us, as a society, to challenge our beliefs about health and reorient material portions of public policy and the economy. It requires embracing a modernized understanding of health, including physical, mental, social, and spiritual health<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="08b63478-2c5e-43c3-8d15-7212a0691cba"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="08b63478-2c5e-43c3-8d15-7212a0691cba" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Spiritual health includes meaning, belonging, purpose, and identity. It does not necessarily require or include religious belief.</span></span></span></a></span>, and the full richness of factors that influence those <a href="/mhi/our-insights/reframing-employee-health-moving-beyond-burnout-to-holistic-health">elements of holistic health</a>. It requires viewing health as an investment, not an expense. It requires scaling solutions that work, which could address 40 percent of the disease burden.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2e563255-b0f1-490c-8753-9e3b8f8b5bda"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2e563255-b0f1-490c-8753-9e3b8f8b5bda" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/healthcare-systems-and-services/our-insights/prioritizing-health-a-prescription-for-prosperity">Prioritizing health: A prescription for prosperity, McKinsey, July 8, 2020.</a></span></span></span></a></span> It requires dramatically more innovation and leadership from institutions outside of the traditional healthcare industry. It requires fully empowering individuals to steward their own health.</p>
<p>Every institution, every leader, and every person has an important role to play.</p>

more to do</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Good health underpins our ability to lead productive and enjoyable lives. Health enables social development and spurs economic growth. Year after year, experts cite social and physical components of health as two of the top three drivers of life satisfaction for individuals.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9802a4b5-5f46-4735-89cb-83486b7bf1fc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9802a4b5-5f46-4735-89cb-83486b7bf1fc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>World happiness report 2021</em>, <a href="https://worldhappiness.report/ed/2021/">Sustainable Development Solutions Network, 2021; social health is the ability of individuals to form healthy and rewarding interpersonal relationships with others.</a></span></span></span></a></span> Global healthcare spending is often over (or about) $8 trillion each year and increases faster than GDP.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="96489c1f-c488-4f64-804c-d9f3d4e9ed85"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="96489c1f-c488-4f64-804c-d9f3d4e9ed85" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240017788">Global spending on health: Weathering the storm</a>, World Health Organization, December 2020.</em></span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Over the past centuries, scientific progress, innovation, greater investment, and trade and exchange across the public, private, and social sectors have led to great advancements in prolonging and improving life. Between 1800 and 2017, average global life expectancy more than doubled, from 30 years to 73 years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4cba2eb2-c617-4378-b72a-9ed005d3bedc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span <hr>
<h5 style="margin-top:0">Since 1960, there has been a significant increase in average global life expectancy.</h5>
<h6 style="margin-top:0"><strong>Life expectancy</strong>,<sup>1</sup> in years</h6>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-o-xl-full-width mck-c-module-wrapper"><div class="mck-u-screen-only" id="interactive-mhi_interactive_test-apps-life-expectancy-heatmap" aria-label="Interactive map visualization illustrating life expectancy across countries in the world over time, from 1960 to 2017. Graph shows how, since 1990, there has been a significant increase the number of years people are expected to live across countries in the world." role="document"></div></div>
<hr>
<p>While its important to recognize and learn from our progress, we must also acknowledge how much more we have to accomplish collectively.</p>
<p>The share of our lives we spend in poor health has not diminished over time. On average, people spend about 50 percent of their lives in less-than-good health including 12 percent in poor health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1c303426-1b61-4595-bcb9-b650706ece3e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1c303426-1b61-4595-bcb9-b650706ece3e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">An individual in good health is defined as a person without a relevant chronic medical condition impacting quality or duration of life, but who may have very well managed chronic conditions or acute injury with high potential for swift and complete recovery. In moderate health defines a person suffering from one or a combination of several acute or chronic conditions that are impacting quality and/or duration of life, but without relevant impairment of activities of daily living. An individual in poor health is defined as suffering from one or more acute or chronic conditions requiring constant or frequent attention by carers and/or impacting activities of daily living significantly and/or reducing quality of life or shortening life expectancy significantly.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d8ed5e06-0293-444d-9be5-37772d4f06f4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d8ed5e06-0293-444d-9be5-37772d4f06f4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis; Life Expectancy at Birth, Total (Years) Database, World Bank Data, accessed 13 December 2021; <em>Global Burden of Disease Study 2019</em>, Demographics 19502019, Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, accessed 13 December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The best available data suggest that this ratio has not changed much in the past 50 years. The upshot is that we spend more time in absolute terms in moderate and poor health than we have at any other point in history. The situation may be gradually worsening, particularly in high-income countries, where chronic conditions now afflict growing numbers of people for a significant portion of their lives (Exhibit 1). Literature on life satisfaction shows that having a substantial health problemdefined as declining from good health to poor healthreduces life satisfaction twice as much as losing a job or becoming widowed, divorced, or separated and five times as much as losing half of ones income.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f43c8580-5fa4-4757-a42a-d0d4dd4355d4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f43c8580-5fa4-4757-a42a-d0d4dd4355d4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Arie Kapteyn et al., <span style="text-decoration:underline">Life satisfaction within and across countries; The role of societal capital and relative income,</span> August 2016; Paul Frijters et al., A happy choice: Wellbeing as the goal of government, Centre for Economic Performance discussion paper number 1658, October 2019, cep.lse.ac.uk; <em><span style="text-decoration:underline">World happiness report 2021</span></em></span></span></span></a></span></p>

September 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> While there is some increasing awareness among healthcare stakeholders regarding sex- and gender-related needs, gaps remain. For example, women make up only one-third of cardiovascular clinical trial participants globally, and large knowledge gaps exist in gender-specific mechanisms and optimal drug doses for women in heart failure.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="62987304-d7f5-4d73-9448-cc3ec9b5ba1b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="62987304-d7f5-4d73-9448-cc3ec9b5ba1b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Carolyn S.P. Lam et al., <a href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31800034/">Sex differences in heart failure</a>, <em>European Heart Journal</em>, December 2019, Volume 40, Number 47.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-24F86C953A314988A6ED15325E6EDF68-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Image of a medical professional analyzing scans over a computer screen and pensive, as introduction to the next section titled Setting a higher aspiration: Adding 45 billion years of higher-quality life." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.2"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-2" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Section 2</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>Setting a higher aspiration: Adding 45 billion years of higher-quality life</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Humanity has the wealth, technology, capacity, and know-how to set and pursue a bolder aspiration for our health. MHIs estimate of achievable impact includes <em>lifting</em> average quality of life; <em>squaring</em>, or increasing the portion of life we spend in good health; and <em>extending</em> life expectancy over the baseline trend (Exhibit 2).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4bab5d9d-85c5-499c-9373-19869a790e9f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4bab5d9d-85c5-499c-9373-19869a790e9f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">On current trajectory, life expectancy is expected to increase 2.6 years on average over the next decade disproportionately in LMICs.</span></span></span></a></span> The gains in LMICs could be even larger than the global average.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/adding%20years%20to%20life%20and%20life%20to%20years/exhibit-2-03-square-the-curve-v2.svg?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Illustrative chart showing the average course of life today and how quality of life/overall health relates to age, highlighting three opportunities to change it: 1) Enhance average quality of life, 2) Improve portion of life spent in good health, and 3) Increase global life expectancy. " src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/adding%20years%20to%20life%20and%20life%20to%20years/exhibit-2-03-square-the-curve-v2.svg?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>What leads us to conclude such a feat is possible?</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Humanity has the wealth, technology, capacity, and know-how to set and pursue a bolder aspiration for our health.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>First, many countries across income levels have, in recent history, achieved significant gains in healthy life expectancy within a decade: 3.8 years in Bolivia, 3.0 years in Ireland, 2.6 in Oman, 6.5 years in South Africa and 4.5 years in Thailand.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d25719fd-4e2c-49f1-9540-b1ed01829b99"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d25719fd-4e2c-49f1-9540-b1ed01829b99" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Healthy Life Expectancy at Birth Years Database, World Health Organization, 20 January 2022; Population (Total) Database, World Bank, 20 January 2022; HALE at birth over the periods 20002010 (for Ireland and Thailand) and 20102019 (for Oman, South Africa and Bolivia): <a href="https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/indicators/indicator-details/GHO/gho-ghe-hale-healthy-life-expectancy-at-birth">WHO income data</a></span></span></span></a></span> There are also countries and regionsthe so-called blue zonesthat appear to have achieved particularly high levels of longevity and stronger health in older age.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="78d4a485-4250-4a06-98f2-2a2c5d00a7b3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">35</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="78d4a485-4250-4a06-98f2-2a2c5d00a7b3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anne Herm, Gianni Pes, and Michel Poulain, The Blue Zones: Areas of exceptional longevity around the world, <em>Vienna Yearbook of Population Research</em>, 2013, Volume 11.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Second, tremendous untapped potential exists in the systematic, equitable, and extensive application of <em>existing knowledge</em>. Previous research led by the McKinsey Global Institute in 2020 concluded that by applying existing and close-to-market interventions, we could eliminate about 40 percent of the current global disease burden by 2040.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b62ca46b-74d0-4806-bed7-eb736e06bab1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">36</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b62ca46b-74d0-4806-bed7-eb736e06bab1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Prioritizing health, July 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Health innovation in the visible pipeline could cut the disease burden by a further 6 to 10 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0d7021f7-3430-4755-b6fb-5d2c621bbf64"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">37</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0d7021f7-3430-4755-b6fb-5d2c621bbf64" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Amy Westervelt, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/apr/30/fda-clinical-trials-gender-gap-epa-nih-institute-of-medicine-cardiovascular-disease">The medical research gender gap: How excluding women from clinical trials is hurting our health</a>, <em>Guardian</em>, April 30, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4554e3e8-4b6d-4e7a-895b-fd10857e0037"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4554e3e8-4b6d-4e7a-895b-fd10857e0037" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Prioritizing health, July 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Third, the worlds response to COVID-19 demonstrates that remarkable innovations and behavior changes can happen quickly when intense focus is combined with resources and collaboration across governments, for-profits, nonprofits, and communities. The world created not only multiple safe and effective vaccines but also numerous treatments and treatment protocols used by millions of clinicians across the world.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9bb10274-43ab-41e6-ace6-cd678396a0b0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9bb10274-43ab-41e6-ace6-cd678396a0b0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">COVID-19 Treatments Database, European Medical Agency, February 2, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="494fa9c6-93c7-477a-9c79-55e2c1a06954"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="494fa9c6-93c7-477a-9c79-55e2c1a06954" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Know your options for COVID-19, US Food & Drug Administration, January 27, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The pandemic also proved that it is possible for billions of people to rapidly modify their behavior in favorable ways (for example, safeguarding protocols, handwashing, self-administered diagnostic testing) when they are convinced its in their interest and are properly equipped. Even outside of the COVID-19 response, other industries (for example, technology, mobile, and automotive) have also demonstrated significant progress in improving product output, safety, and quality at the same or lower cost over a single decade.</p>
<p>The remainder of this article describes the shifts MHI believes society will need to make to realize the possible gains in both life expectancy and quality of life.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-EAD9857EA44249EF97E6466B8500CB4D-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Image of a person looking at produce from a garden and smiling, as introduction to the next section titled The foundation: Embracing a modernized understanding of health." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.2"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-3" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Section 3</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>The foundation: Embracing a modernized understanding of health</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Historically, society has defined health in terms of the presence or absence of disease. Someone is deemed to be in good health if disease has no impact on their life expectancy or physical function. To add up to 45 billion years of higher-quality life, MHI proposes that we embrace a broader definition of health that better aligns with individual aspirations and the latest scientific research. The World Health Organization (WHO) proposed just such a broad definition of health, with a greater emphasis on well-being, back in 1948: health is a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity. The subcomponents of spiritual health<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bb91b287-3bb9-4e1a-82cb-e2ec81f18ba8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">41</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bb91b287-3bb9-4e1a-82cb-e2ec81f18ba8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Spiritual health includes meaning, belonging, purpose, and identity. It does not necessarily require or include religious belief.</span></span></span></a></span> have also been recognized as relevant to health for decades.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c05e7532-88cb-4250-a7d9-d52ae56dc89b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">42</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c05e7532-88cb-4250-a7d9-d52ae56dc89b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">S.K. Chaturvedi, Nera Dhar, and Deoki Nandan, Spiritual health, the fourth dimension: A public health perspective, <em>Who South-East Asia Journal of Public Health</em>, January 2013, Volume 2; Francesco Chirico, Spiritual well-being in the 21st century: It is time to review the current WHOs health definition, <em>Journal of Health and Social Sciences</em>, March 2016, Volume 1; Christina M. Puchalski, Integrating spirituality into patient care: an essential element of person-centered care, <em>Polish Archives of Internal Medicine</em>, September 2013, Volume 123, Number 9; Giancarlo Lucchetti et al., Spirituality and health in the medical schools in Brazil, <em>BMC Medical Education</em>, August 2012, Volume 12; <em>Spiritual aspects of health: Global strategy for health for all by the year 2000</em>, South-East Asia Advisory Committee on Medical Research, World Health Organization, March 1984.</span></span></span></a></span> MHI uses the term spiritual because it is the most common way for other healthcare institutions and leaders to refer to these concepts. Strong spiritual health does not necessarily imply the adoption of religious beliefs. Unfortunately, a broad vision of health has not taken hold. MHI proposes that society fully embrace the proposed foundation and act on it.</p>
<p>MHI proposes an understanding of health with the following characteristics:</p>
<ul>
    <li><strong>Holistic. </strong>It recognizes the relevance and interdependencies of physical, mental, social, and spiritual dimensions.</li>
    <li><strong>Uses a positive frame. </strong>The objective on each dimension is <em>optimal</em> health given an individuals physiological capacity, not simply the absence of disease.</li>
    <li><strong>Anchored in function. </strong>Health is relevant only to the extent it enables people to live fullyto build relationships, work or volunteer, and contribute to society while also enjoying pursuits.</li>
    <li><strong>Affected by a multitude of influences. </strong>This understanding of health recognizes the vast set of factors that affect health, including personal attributes, personal behaviors, interventions, and environmental attributes.</li>
    <li><strong>Objective. </strong>It is measurable across time, geographies, health systems, and cultures.</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge mck-c-module-wrapper"><div class="mck-u-screen-only" id="interactive-mhi_interactive_test-apps-launch-article-holistic-health" aria-label="Holistic Health" role="document"></div></div>
<p>Strong anecdotal and empirical evidence suggests that these four health dimensions collectively contribute to both longevity and quality of life. Individuals often suffer harm when their health fails along even one of these dimensions. For example, global data indicate that severe mental health disorders can reduce life expectancy anywhere from 10 to 25 years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4a80a9d1-d7f5-4abf-8562-70d70a9dc1fb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">52</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4a80a9d1-d7f5-4abf-8562-70d70a9dc1fb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="https://www.who.int/mental_health/management/info_sheet.pdf">WHO, Information sheet: Premature death among people with severe mental disorders</a></span></span></span></a></span> On the social health dimension, loneliness and social isolation are associated with higher risks of heart attack and strokes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0741bbac-f2e9-4c8a-a6fd-2082bf93e40d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">53</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0741bbac-f2e9-4c8a-a6fd-2082bf93e40d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The Loneliness Epidemic, US Health Resources and Services Administration, January 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> In fact, research shows that loneliness and social isolation can be as damaging to an individuals health as smoking 15 cigarettes per day,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dcf79c10-741f-4dfd-b670-b9c12dc73fc8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">54</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dcf79c10-741f-4dfd-b670-b9c12dc73fc8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kavita Chawla et al., Prevalence of loneliness amongst older people in high-income countries: A systematic review and meta-analysis, <em>PLOS One</em>, July 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> which is especially concerning when we note that up to 29 percent of elderly people report feeling lonely.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6f3009b6-ed1b-4333-bca3-f25cd01d0d5a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">55</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6f3009b6-ed1b-4333-bca3-f25cd01d0d5a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kim ES, et al.; Purpose in life and reduced incidence of stroke in older adults: 'The Health and Retirement Study'. J Psychosom Res. 2013 May</span></span></span></a></span> A lack of social connections has been associated with an increase in inflammation at the same magnitude as physical inactivity in adolescence, and in old age, the effect of social isolation on hypertension exceeded that of clinical risk factors such as diabetes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cf889ea1-bcba-4654-94a8-e2bd19e0ea9c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">56</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cf889ea1-bcba-4654-94a8-e2bd19e0ea9c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Yang Claire Yang et al., Social relationships and physiological determinants of longevity across the human life span, <em>PNAS</em>, January 2016, Volume 113, Number 3.</span></span></span></a></span> On a more hopeful note, for older American adults, greater purpose in life has been linked with a lower risk of stroke.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0e28fb24-65c7-4d94-b34b-95dff78e2866"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">57</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0e28fb24-65c7-4d94-b34b-95dff78e2866" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Purpose in life, May 2013.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>A more complete understanding of human health also includes acknowledging the extensive set of factors that affect it. These <strong>influencing factors</strong> fall into four groups: personal attributes, personal behaviors, environmental attributes, and interventions. Personal behaviors refer to individual actions such as sleep, diet, exercise, and adherence to treatment regimens. Personal attributes are individual characteristics such as genetics, education, and relationships that typically cannot be modified, at least in the short term. Environmental attributes are factors that shape the health of all individuals within a given context and include the contexts political and economic system as well as global threats such as climate change. Interventions refer to deliberate actions intended to bring about change, such as clinical interventions, financial support, or incentives.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-F5439AE9B2534DE5AECCCEC9CAFD6873-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Image of a woman with a child in a front-facing baby carrier and smiling while looking at her phone, as introduction to the next section titled From possibility to reality: Six shifts." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.2"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-4" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Section 4</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>From possibility to reality: Six shifts</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Our research suggests that adding up to 45 billion years of higher-quality life would require at least six material shifts in societal mindsets and actions (Exhibit 3). These shifts are highly interdependent and mutually reinforcing, and adopting them would represent a material reorientation of public policy and the economy.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/adding%20years%20to%20life%20and%20life%20to%20years/exhibit-4-06-six-shifts-v2.svg?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Table listing the six material shifts in societal mindsets and actions that the article elaborates on, based on research that suggests this is at least part of what is required to add up to 45 billion years of higher-quality life globally. For each, the Exhibit shows Where we are today and Where we need to be." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/adding%20years%20to%20life%20and%20life%20to%20years/exhibit-4-06-six-shifts-v2.svg?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Shift 1. Invest more, disproportionately on prevention and promoting optimal health</h3>
<p>Unlocking up to 45 billion years of higher-quality life will require individuals, governments, and private institutions to invest more financial and <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/human-capital-at-work-the-value-of-experience">human capital</a> as a percentage of GDP to improve health. Greater investment in health-related interventions is justified in areas traditionally considered part of the healthcare system and in other parts of the economysuch as education, nutrition and agriculture, consumer products, financial services, and technologythat have the potential to improve health.</p>
<p>The case for greater investment in health is economically sound and responsive to citizen and consumer preferences. McKinsey Global Institutes <em>Prioritizing health</em> report estimates that improving the health of the global population by effectively scaling known interventions could generate an ROI of two to four times, even when only considering economic benefits. Individuals consistently place a high priority on improving health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8c8ae563-81ed-45d0-b863-d54f48df1de9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">58</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8c8ae563-81ed-45d0-b863-d54f48df1de9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Prioritizing health, July 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Year after year, experts cite social and physical elements of health as two of the top three drivers of life satisfaction for individuals.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="29ae2fbb-8743-4e0a-9f02-4669ba89c66d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">59</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="29ae2fbb-8743-4e0a-9f02-4669ba89c66d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="https://worldhappiness.report/ed/2021/">World happiness report 2021</a></em>; social health is the ability of individuals to form healthy and rewarding interpersonal relationships with others.</span></span></span></a></span> A significant positive correlation exists between greater investment in health and improvements in living standards and wealth across countries and time. MHI believes a causal link exists. High-income countries do not appear to have reached a point of diminishing returns.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="49a22554-bf90-4531-b918-9feb8608a169"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">60</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="49a22554-bf90-4531-b918-9feb8608a169" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="https://worldhappiness.report/ed/2021/">In 2019, EU countries devoted on average 8.3 percent of their GDP to healthcare; this figure has remained largely unchanged since 2014 as growth in health spending remained broadly in line with overall economic growth. In the US, the share of national health expenditure has increased 6 percentage points over the last two decades, in line with the pace of economic growth. Health Expenditure in Relation to GDP, <em>Health at a Glance: Europe 2020: State of Health in the EU Cycle</em>, 2020; Current Health Expenditure (% of GDP), World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure Database, World Bank, January 19, 2021; Historical: National Health Expenditure Data, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, January 19, 2021.</a></span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>MHI further proposes disproportionately investing in disease prevention and health promotion in addition to treatment to help people truly thrive. Promotion is defined here as actions that help individuals achieve and sustain the best possible physical, mental, social, and spiritual health given their intrinsic biological capacity.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Society should empower people to thrive, going beyond treatment to promoting a healthy way of life for us all.</p></blockquote></div>
<span class="mhi--video"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="FullBleedMedia_mck-c-fullbleed-media__WIpmy mck-c-module-wrapper"><div class="FullBleedMedia_mck-c-fullbleed-media__video-wrapper__Cd0v7"><video class="FullBleedMedia_mck-c-fullbleed-media__video__Yn2HU mck-u-screen-only" id="bcVideo6299301475001" muted="" loop="" autoplay="" playsinline=""></video></div><div class="mck-o-container FullBleedMedia_mck-c-fullbleed-media__wrapper__z0yvu"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped FullBleedMedia_mck-c-fullbleed-media__wrapper-content__dB_sH"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 FullBleedMedia_mck-c-fullbleed-media__wrapper-text__nqQYU"></div></div></div></div></span>
<p>Currently, health spending is heavily tilted toward curative care. OECD countries spend just 2.8 percent of their health budgets on organized prevention programs such as vaccinations, disease screenings, and health education.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="24de1eb5-e59f-4a67-9a9e-4d2209a277c9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">61</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="24de1eb5-e59f-4a67-9a9e-4d2209a277c9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Countries need to up spending commitments on health promotion, urge think tanks, International Longevity Centre, November 2021.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="90bbbb99-e82f-4b7e-9e7a-88cdd70d7043"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">62</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="90bbbb99-e82f-4b7e-9e7a-88cdd70d7043" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Health spending in most OECD countries rises, with the U.S. far outstripping all others, OECD, March 2004.</span></span></span></a></span> Low-income economies spend ten times as much (as a proportion of budget) as OECD countries do on preventative measures, which amounts to 20 to 35 percent of these low-income economies healthcare budgets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5b677803-5a10-4666-894a-45f3ec6baadd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">63</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5b677803-5a10-4666-894a-45f3ec6baadd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Global spending on health: A world in transition</em>, World Health Organization, December 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> At the moment, most investment and innovation in achieving optimal health come from the private sector. The global wellness market, for example, is valued at $1.5 trillion, roughly four times the size of what governments and NGOs spend globally on preventive care and health promotion.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7bfb38f2-0de9-470c-9808-e8607d8b293c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">64</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7bfb38f2-0de9-470c-9808-e8607d8b293c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis; Global wellness-market figure pulled from McKinseys Future of Wellness report and encapsulates products ranging from personal health trackers to nonsurgical aesthetic procedures.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Finally, MHI proposes disproportionately investing in under-resourced populations as both a moral imperative and a good financial decision. Improving the health of populations with historically reduced access to care or worse-than-average health outcomes can give societies a potent economic boost. Better health is associated with improved labor productivity and higher income. For example, 11 percent of economic growth in LMICs from 1970 to 2000 resulted from reduced rates of adult mortality.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f678b684-6715-4cb8-ac51-b3935e21af02"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">65</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f678b684-6715-4cb8-ac51-b3935e21af02" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Dean T. Jamison, Laurence J. Lau, and Jia Wang, Healths contribution to economic growth in an environment of partially endogenous technical progress, in <em>Health and economic growth: Findings and policy implications</em>, ed. Guillem <a href="https://www.econbiz.de/Search/Results?lookfor=person%3A%22L%C3%B3pez+i+Casasnovas%2C+Guillem%22">Lpez-Casasnovas</a>, (Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 2005), 6791; Blake C. Alkire et al., The economic consequences of mortality amenable to high-quality health care in low- and middle-income countries, <em>Health Affairs</em>, June 2018, Volume 37, Number 6. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>As a first step to realizing this shift, governments might consider conducting a health opportunity assessment across all government agencies, including those outside of healthcare (for example, environment, education, treasury, trade, agriculture, housing, and infrastructure) to understand the most critical links to health and to unearth potential high-ROI investments for consideration, including the net effect of laws, regulations, and government activity on private sector activity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="036ea8fe-c9a0-4e33-8375-e8848f82804e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">66</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="036ea8fe-c9a0-4e33-8375-e8848f82804e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">A similar perspective with a UK lens is explored in <em>Whose Health Is It, Anyway?,</em> by Sally C. Davies and Jonathan Pearson-Stuttard, published by Oxford University Press in 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Shift 2. Improve measurement of a modernized understanding of health with better data</h3>
<p>Attaining the aspiration requires improving global standards and systems to measure a modernized understanding of health, collecting significantly more comparative data on each element and dramatically increasing transparency.</p>
<p>The rationale is straightforward: measurement is foundational to improvement. Measurement helps us understand what works and what doesnt so we can allocate resources effectively. Conversely, weak (or nonexistent) measurement leads to waste and prevents us from investing more in what might be promising innovation. Overly generalized measurements are also ineffective; for example, the absence of a diagnostic framework for autism specifically for women leads to under-diagnosis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a40f6c5e-84b6-420a-b366-caea2cce06c8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">67</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a40f6c5e-84b6-420a-b366-caea2cce06c8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jean Golding, Ginny Russell, and Colin Steer, Social and demographic factors that influence the diagnosis of autistic spectrum disorders, <em>Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology</em>, October 2010, Volume 46.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="69c935e3-717f-42f3-8682-be366408694f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">68</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="69c935e3-717f-42f3-8682-be366408694f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Katharina Dworzynski et al., How different are girls and boys above and below the diagnostic threshold for autism spectrum disorders?, <em>Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry</em>, June 2012, Volume 51, Number 8.</span></span></span></a></span> Its clear that researchers need subgroup-specific data collection and measurement initiatives.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>We estimate that fewer than 5 percent of factors that influence and measure a modern understanding of health are defined consistently, captured systematically, and made broadly available as data.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>MHI estimates that fewer than 5 percent of factors that influence and measure a modern understanding of health are defined consistently (or at all), captured systematically and made broadly available as data. Most elements of a modern definition of health have very modest, if any, reliable measurement standards or data, including social and spiritual health and large categories of influencing factors such as the role of nutrition, employment, housing, and sleep. An estimated 75 percent of studies related to health can be classified as having primary endpoints that measure physical health, while just 12 percent address mental health, 6 percent address social health, and 1 percent examine spiritual health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="be1a88ff-48fb-486d-8964-446f070e9e8c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">69</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="be1a88ff-48fb-486d-8964-446f070e9e8c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sample analysis based on PubMed.</span></span></span></a></span> Most countries have very limited or no data regarding mental health, and data that are comparable across regions are lacking. For example, more than 100 countries have no data about mental health conditions among adolescents.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ff92dd25-2055-49f1-aa83-1fd52eaa79c5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">70</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ff92dd25-2055-49f1-aa83-1fd52eaa79c5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">H.E. Erskine et al., <span style="text-decoration:underline"><a href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26786507/#:~:text=Results%3A%20Mean%20global%20coverage%20of,no%20data%20for%20any%20disorder">The global coverage of prevalence data for mental disorders in children and adolescents</a></span>, <em>Epidemiology and Psychiatric Sciences</em>, August 2017, Volume 4.</span></span></span></a></span> And of the 23 mental-health indicators measured by OECD, only twolife satisfaction and death by suicidewere available in more than 90 percent of OECD countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3923e047-7105-4720-b240-f372044e8b10"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">71</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3923e047-7105-4720-b240-f372044e8b10" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Key findings and recommendations, <em>A new benchmark for mental health systems: Tackling the social and economic costs of mental ill-health</em>, OECD, June 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Finally, there is only a modest attempt to define or consistently measure the extent to which individuals have achieved optimal possible health.</p>
<p>Even physical health measurements, the area with the best standards and data, offer considerable room for improvement. High-income countries capture primarily disease prevalence and select health interventions (for example, prescriptions, office visits, and procedures). Few data are systematically captured or available with respect to function itself or health status such as mobility, toxin levels, pain, and sexual function. Challenges in lower-income countries are more fundamental and include undigitized patient records, siloed reporting due to unintegrated care, and lack of access to diagnostic technologies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9f2df476-d8f8-4ba7-8d11-fe9e22c5ae16"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">72</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9f2df476-d8f8-4ba7-8d11-fe9e22c5ae16" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Philomena Ngugi et al., <a href="https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0244917">Development of standard indicators to assess use of electronic health record systems implemented in low-and-medium-income countries, PLOS One, January 2021.</a></span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="69a86f74-8a72-4400-a68b-21d67f42fddf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">73</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="69a86f74-8a72-4400-a68b-21d67f42fddf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Susannah H. Mayhew, Nicholas Mays, and Sandra Mounier-Jack, Integrated care: Learning between high-income, and low- and middle-income country health systems, <em><a href="https://academic.oup.com/heapol/article/32/suppl_4/iv6/4661666">Health Policy and Planning</a></em>, November 2017, Volume 32.</span></span></span></a></span> Positive examples, such as India, have shown how LMIC economies can still build robust nationwide health registries over time.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="46e0c00e-c15c-4ebd-b123-1eb1a524a3b9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">74</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="46e0c00e-c15c-4ebd-b123-1eb1a524a3b9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Katherine Hay, Manoj Mohanan, and Nachiket Mor, Quality of health care in India: Challenges, priorities, and the road ahead, <em>Health Affairs</em>, October 2016, Volume 35, Number 10.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>An example of the tangible downside associated with weak measurement is the challenge high-income countries face in subjecting nonpharmaceutical interventions to rigorous empirical analysis. Since 2007, only 11 percent of food-related health claimsa large component of the nonpharmaceutical-intervention categoryhave met the EU criteria for robust scientific evidence.<span <h3>Shift 3. Scale what works</h3>
<p>McKinsey Global Institutes <em>Prioritizing health</em> report estimates that by applying existing and proven interventions, the global disease burden could be reduced by about 40 percent (Exhibit 4).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d7657f8a-e761-464a-a793-3a8d47cff0aa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">79</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d7657f8a-e761-464a-a793-3a8d47cff0aa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Prioritizing health, July 2020. </span></span></span></a></span> Scaling known interventions could reduce child mortality by 65 percent and help a typical 65-year-old to be as healthy as a typical 55-year-old today. These numbers only account for improvements in physical and, to some extent, mental health. The potential for improved outcomes when health is considered more broadly is even greater. For high-income countries, most of the potential is in addressing diabetes, cancer, and cardiovascular disease. Low-income countries would benefit from more investment in known, basic health infrastructure.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1ccf405e-5608-4c49-b810-065f10193696"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">80</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1ccf405e-5608-4c49-b810-065f10193696" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Prioritizing health, July 2020. </span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, scaling up largely preventative solutions and targeting infectious diseases and nutritional disorders as well as maternal, neonatal, and child health are high-potential improvements.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/adding%20years%20to%20life%20and%20life%20to%20years/exhibit-6-07-voronoi-v2.svg?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Voronoi chart (i.e., chart with partitions of a plane into regions divided by individual data points using polygonal boundaries), showing the potential for disease reduction in Disability-Adjusted Life Years, by intervention type." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/adding%20years%20to%20life%20and%20life%20to%20years/exhibit-6-07-voronoi-v2.svg?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Past experience shows that scaling existing technologies can be very challengingthe global rollout of hepatitis B vaccines took more than 17 years, and survival after a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes in some LMICs is as low as one year, often due to the unaffordability of insulin.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dc97d89b-fa39-4c38-9804-4e2ce803f2f8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">81</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span April 2009, Volume 5, Number 4.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL 7.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ebf1af34-9594-4dc3-9273-22f30701c8e0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">83</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span Yudkin, Insulin for the world's poorest countries, <em>Lancet</em>, March 2001, Volume 355, Number 9.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>To scale what works, societies need awareness and a commitment from people, governments, payers (including employers), and healthcare providers to adapt. Each group has an opportunity to overcome myopia and biases and establish strategies, policies, and incentives to increase the application of known solutions with high ROI. In many cases, such adaptation also requires greater net investment, as previously stated.</p>
<p>Another key to scaling what works is applying proven interventions across contexts, including countries and populations. Literature extensively describes differences in health outcomes for the same diseases by health provider, even within the same geography.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0d19ca2f-a693-48bb-af76-21b8308efa2c"><sup
