For example, the Aravind Eye Care System in southern India developed a successful and efficient system for delivering high-quality and low-cost cataract surgery.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cfb58f7a-2a31-46f5-960f-f39cdf1aa728"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">88</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cfb58f7a-2a31-46f5-960f-f39cdf1aa728" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Profitable Audacity: One Company's Success Story, Harvard Business Review, January 2012.</span></span></span></a></span> Despite the potential for meaningful application in other parts of the world, including high-income countries, this system remains primarily anchored in the local context.</p>
<h3>Shift 4. Innovate more, and more quickly</h3>
<p>More innovation in all forms will be required, including in such areas as business models, government policies, incentive schemes, pharmaceuticals, medical devices, clinical standards, mobile apps, medical products, process improvements, and novel applications of existing technologies such as artificial intelligence. Increasing innovation will require more foundational research, better collaboration to break through silos, and quicker and more effective nurturing and scaling of the most promising concepts.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>The exceptional pace of development and deployment of vaccines for COVID-19 is illustrative of the opportunity to drastically accelerate progress in public health.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Innovation, along with greater investment in health, has been the driving force behind most advances in health. Once scientists identified the link between diabetes and insulin production in the pancreas a century ago, a continuous chain of discovery and commercialization has transformed the lives of diabetes patients.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d5895441-e867-4061-bae0-07d05ee5095f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">89</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d5895441-e867-4061-bae0-07d05ee5095f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Thomas Kjeldsen and Peter Kurtzhals, A hundred years of insulin innovation: When science meets technology, <em>Diabetes</em>, September 2021, Volume 70, Number 9.</span></span></span></a></span> Cancer mortality in the United States fell 32 percent from 1991 to 2019,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cbd3aa70-b7e4-4015-95d7-6e02956fc41b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">90</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cbd3aa70-b7e4-4015-95d7-6e02956fc41b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Rebecca L. Seigel et al., <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s43018-021-00192-x">Cancer Statistics, 2022</a>, <em>CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians</em>, January 2022, Volume 72, Number 1.</span></span></span></a></span> in part due to new surgical techniques, detection tools, and targeted therapies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3da5039c-f36d-4118-9b09-728692d5a9f4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">91</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3da5039c-f36d-4118-9b09-728692d5a9f4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s43018-021-00192-x">Advancing cancer therapy</a>, <em>Nature Cancer</em>, March 2021, Volume 2.</span></span></span></a></span> The exceptional pace of development and deployment of vaccines for COVID-19 is illustrative of the opportunity to drastically accelerate progress in public health when societal will, incentives, and resources are aligned. COVID-19 vaccines progressed from discovery to global distribution of the finished product in less than 12 months. Vaccine development is a high-risk process that traditionally takes more than a decade to complete. Prior to COVID-19, the fastest vaccine ever developedfor mumps in 1967took four years from discovery to market launch.</p>
<p>Yet there are many areas where innovation has not occurred as hoped, often in the context of market failures. Despite the urgent threat of antimicrobial resistance (AMR), innovation in new antibiotics and alternatives has been weak, due in part to lack of incentives to invest in research and development.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1d867269-16c6-4613-ad26-1f84a7889e7f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">92</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1d867269-16c6-4613-ad26-1f84a7889e7f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Antimicrobial resistance: Invest in innovation and research, and boost R&D and access, IACG, June 2018.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2012eb04-2b93-4251-b812-fb4b220c5292"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">93</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2012eb04-2b93-4251-b812-fb4b220c5292" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Global shortage of innovative antibiotics fuel emergence and spread of drug-resistance, World Health Organization, April 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The antibiotic pipeline is substantially weaker than those for other therapeutic areas, such as treatment for cancer. One comparison: between 2017 and 2020, 1,751 immuno-oncology drugs were in preclinical and research phase, and 45 received approval. In the same period, just 292 antibiotics were in preclinical and research phase, and 11 received approval.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4359d8a8-8e1c-4614-af36-c41cdc56380b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">94</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4359d8a8-8e1c-4614-af36-c41cdc56380b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">FDA, New Drug Therapy Approvals (2021, 2020, 2019, 2018, 2017) and Biologic Approvals by year; approvals between 1 July 2017 and Sept 30, 2020/ approvals anti-infectives/anti-bacterials. Only FDA approvals counted. Count of drugs, not indications. Approvals given for total/new molecule.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1d685fa6-5704-4498-be65-bd886c5829eb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">95</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1d685fa6-5704-4498-be65-bd886c5829eb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240021303">2020 antibacterial agents in clinical and preclinical development: An overview and analysis</a>, World Health Organization, April 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In addition to even more innovation from the life sciences industry, humanity would benefit from substantially more innovation from other industries and domains, especially via the application of emerging technologies<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d636f5ce-2466-40c2-968f-739b37c00b54"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">96</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d636f5ce-2466-40c2-968f-739b37c00b54" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jacomo Corbo, Nicolaus Henke, and Ivan Ostojic, <a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-top-trends-in-tech">The top trends in tech,</a> McKinsey, June 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> such as applied artificial intelligence, next-generation computing, and distributed computing. In addition, society has yet to realize the full potential of digital health innovation to improve health outcomes. Good momentum for catalyzing new or greater innovation exists, especially among venture- and private-equity-backed companies. Venture capital investments in digital health reached an all-time high of $29 billion in 2021, nearly doubling 2020s investments.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a8350b57-eab4-4534-bb00-e46c34c861a7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">97</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a8350b57-eab4-4534-bb00-e46c34c861a7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Bill Evans, Adriana Krasniansky, and Megan Zweig, 2021 year-end digital health funding: Seismic shifts beneath the surface, Rock Health, January 10, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Promising concepts include wearables (for example, activity tracking, cardiac anomaly detection, patches for blood sugar monitoring, physiotherapy for pain relief with body-posture detection), telesurgery, and AI-enabled diagnostics. Telemedicine exploded worldwide in 2020 due to COVID-19; in the United States, it grew by 3,800 percent in 2020, and some consumers continue to indicate a preference for it.<span <div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>We need to create an ecosystem of innovation by looking at all processes and influencing factors and engaging all stakeholders who affect a desired health outcome.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Finally, capturing the full potential impact from innovation will require us to rethink the way we innovate. We need to create an ecosystem of innovation by looking at all processes and influencing factors and engaging all stakeholders who affect a desired health outcome. This kind of innovation allows for better implementation mechanisms, end-to-end coordination, and collaboration to effectively and efficiently support sustainable behavior change and improve patient pathways. One such example is the Stop TB Partnership, which aims to end tuberculosis worldwide by 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d7c105c-450b-42bb-b5be-60974402dc4e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">100</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d7c105c-450b-42bb-b5be-60974402dc4e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Re-imagining TB Care, <em>Stop TB Partnership</em>, accessed February 26, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The organization defined the optimal end-to-end care flow for tuberculosis, identified key interventions, and mapped stakeholders against each. It then aligned all contributors on the same data standards and coordinated their efforts, which resulted in an ecosystem that is both effective and scalable. Another example of an effective ecosystem can be found in Amsterdam, where multiple city departments (beyond the health department) work together in a coalition to achieve highly ambitious health and well-being targets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" 2026</em>, Fast-Track Cities, May 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Impactful innovation requires integrated, purposeful action across governments and the private sector. Governments might consider how to adapt investments, budgets, regulations and regular processes, intellectual property schemes, reimbursement principles, and laws to better catalyze innovation in areas with the greatest societal needs. Government action may be particularly relevant where the risk of market failure is high. Individuals and private payers, including insurers and employers, might consider how to adapt their consumption patterns and reimbursement policies to seek and reward promising innovations. Finally, greater innovation requires businesses from outside the healthcare sector to view health as an emerging or core market to enter, disrupt, and pursue.</p>
<h3>Shift 5. Unleash the full potential of all industries</h3>
<p>Achieving the set aspiration requires institutions outside of the traditional healthcare industry to pursue health-related business opportunities much more aggressively, better enable and empower their employees, and better define and honor health-related environmental, social, and governance (ESG) commitments.</p>
<p>Health is deeply relevant to every business in the world, at minimum because employers affect the health of their employees, and the health of employees affects their performance. Sixty-eight percent of companies say employee well-being and mental health is a top strategic priority.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6f833e04-3a55-4354-aeb3-b310f403f59e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">104</sup><span That needs to change, <em>Fortune</em>, March 25, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> Fewer have developed or implemented systemic policies to improve employee health.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/adding%20years%20to%20life%20and%20life%20to%20years/exhibit-7-08-sp-v2.svg?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Bar chart showing the split of S&P 500 companies that have offerings that directly affect people's health, including those in the Healthcare Industry (which make up 10-15% of the total) and other companies with a strong link to health (40-50% of the total)." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/adding%20years%20to%20life%20and%20life%20to%20years/exhibit-7-08-sp-v2.svg?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Even more critically, MHI estimates that 40 to 45 percent of companies in the S&P 500 that are not considered part of the healthcare industry deliver products or services that directly affect the health of individuals (Exhibit 5), sometimes favorably and sometimes unfavorably. Industries with highly health-relevant products or services include food and nutrition, consumer products, social media, transportation, gaming, travel, consumer financial services, non-health-related insurance, housing, and heating and cooling systems. Companies in these industries have an opportunity to leverage their relevance much more aggressively to explore even more significant, more disruptive entry into healthcare in both traditional and emerging domains. In some cases, companies face an imperative to understand and mitigate the potentially unfavorable effect of their products or services.</p>
<p>Moreover, companies that dont have a direct or strong link to health, still have the opportunity to empower employees to improve their health and honor health-related environmental, social and government commitments.</p>
<h3>Shift 6. Empower individuals to steward their own health</h3>
<p>To unlock up to 45 billion years of higher-quality life, individuals need to be empowered as the primary stewards of their own health and their loved ones health. Individual behaviors are the single biggest driver of an individuals health. Multiple studies have shown that modifiable behaviorsincluding diet, activity levels, sleep, adherence to medication, and tobacco usecontribute to as much as 60 percent of deaths worldwide.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d29ac624-5795-4ad3-ba60-3104a506e3b2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">108</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d29ac624-5795-4ad3-ba60-3104a506e3b2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Robert F. Kushner and Kirsten Webb Sorenson, Lifestyle medicine: The future of chronic disease management, <em>Current Opinion in Endocrinology, Diabetes and Obesity</em>, October 2013, Volume 20, Number 5.</span></span></span></a></span> Individual mindsets and behaviors are likely even more relevant when considered through the lens of a modernized, holistic understanding of health that also includes the role of mental, social, and spiritual functioning. Almost every aspect of our lives and most of our choices affect our health.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Consumers across cultures and countries are increasingly demanding more empowerment.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Consumers across cultures and countries are increasingly demanding more empowerment. Their expectations are shaped by experiences of speed, convenience, personalization, and access to information from other industries, and they expect the same with respect to their health. Trust in institutions is declining in many regions, increasing the felt need of many individuals to be more self-directed.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9459b6c6-97b4-4822-9fb4-198841d7a67d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">109</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9459b6c6-97b4-4822-9fb4-198841d7a67d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jonathan Perry, Trust in public institutions: Trends and implications for economic security, UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs, July 20, 2021; Esteban Ortiz-Ospina and Max Roser, Trust, Our World in Data, 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> Finally, in many parts of the world, healthcare remains largely self-funded, which puts an even greater onus on the individual.</p>
<p>Recent experience shows that massive changes of behavior are possible. Billions of people significantly changed their daily actions, such as wearing face masks and social distancing, to protect themselves and their families during the COVID-19 pandemic. Insights from behavioral economics also show how to motivate and empower individuals so they are most likely to make decisions that are in their own best interest. Nudgingwhich behavioral science defines as a means of altering peoples behavior without restricting their choices or changing their economic incentivescan influence the behavior and decision making of individuals and groups. For example, nudging has been shown to improve hand hygiene among healthcare workers to decrease the number of healthcare-associated infections.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1f0b57ea-6a72-4832-b5e1-a8641ac360fe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">110</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1f0b57ea-6a72-4832-b5e1-a8641ac360fe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">M.G. Caris et al., Nudging to improve hand hygiene, <em>The Journal of Hospital Infection</em>, September 2017, Volume 98, Number 4.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition to purposeful nudging, social networks and their associated culture, mindsets, and behaviors are highly correlated with individuals health-relevant decisions and behaviors. Empowering individuals will require action from the government, more innovation, and adaptation from traditional healthcare stakeholders. Governments can consider how they might adapt laws, regulations, incentives, and government-operated healthcare services to better empower people. Governments might also consider how to adapt (or create) environments, structures, or systems to make it easier for consumers to make healthy choices.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Addressing health inequity</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body">As highlighted in this report, addressing health inequities across countries and populations is both the right thing to do and a requirement to reach the aspiration. MHI acknowledges that this is an arena where more research and work could be critical, especially to achieve impact at scale. Moreover, equity priorities will vary considerably across communities based on contexts and cultures. That said, research suggests a few foundational actions are needed. The first is to acknowledge and measure inequity to encourage accountability, motivate action, and better understand root causes of poor health. The second is for governments, businesses, and social institutions to be even more intentional in creating focused strategies to address inequities. Finally, MHI believes a focus on equity can and should be considered and integrated into all other actions to improve health, both to uncover potential opportunities to reduce inequity and to mitigate the risk of unintentionally exacerbating it.</div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Empowering individuals will require substantially more technology-based innovation, including mobile or remote access that optimizes exercise, sleep, caloric intake, posture, and the like. Innovation that empowers individuals is exploding across low-, middle-, and high-income countries. In rural India, for example, smartphones enable individuals to have greater access to healthcare providers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8a1ed93d-3269-43ec-90c0-94a339cbd780"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">111</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8a1ed93d-3269-43ec-90c0-94a339cbd780" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Smart doctor: How smartphones hold the key to improving rural health in India, Nanyang Technological University, July 16, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Approximately 200 million Chinese consumers have used Ping Ans Good Doctor mobile platform to receive consultation, referrals, and appointments.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c95dc9f2-7a9c-4239-b90f-b82f5dd7e0db"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">112</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c95dc9f2-7a9c-4239-b90f-b82f5dd7e0db" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Technology empowers Ping Ans health care amid coronavirus, Ping An, August 13, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In 2019, 21 percent of Americans reported using smart watches or fitness trackers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a4b05dee-1b32-4667-95eb-91c3c1aef244"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">113</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a4b05dee-1b32-4667-95eb-91c3c1aef244" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Emily A. Vogels, About one-in-five Americans use a smart watch or fitness tracker, Pew Research Center, January 9, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Finally, healthcare stakeholders, especially provider institutions and clinicians, might consider how to embrace many patients desire to be self-directed. Providers have an opportunity to operate more as coaches who help patients define and execute a coauthored care plan. Providers also have an opportunity to embrace many of the technology-based solutions emerging outside the traditional healthcare industry cited above.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-2881A24C75CD4139BCB6C0405C69A95C-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Image of a medical professional giving an injection to a child that is being held by their mother, as introduction to the next section titled Entering the arena." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.2"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-5" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Section 5</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>Entering the arena</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Dramatically improving our health requires an ecosystem approach  exchanging ideas, aligning around standards, working across multiple stakeholder silos. It will require unprecedented collaboration to shift societys mindsets and actions enough to realize possible gains in life expectancy and quality of life.</p>
<p>McKinsey Health Institute is an enduring, non-profit-generating global entity within McKinsey that strives to catalyze actions across continents, sectors, and communities to extend and improve lives. MHI is committed to contributing to this collective ecosystem. MHI is fostering a strong network of organizations committed to this aspiration through a range of collaboration types  convening and enabling leaders, advancing research, creating and promoting open-access data assets, and stimulating innovation. MHI is sharing resources, innovations, data, and findings in the public domain so others can replicate what proves effective and looks to its ecosystem partners to commit to the same.</p>
<p>MHI welcomes connection with committed organizations interested in building out this ecosystem together. MHI is actively seeking opportunities to collaborate across its identified six shifts as well as seven initial key focus areas: brain health, healthy living, infectious diseases, equity and health, sustainability and health, healthy aging, and healthcare-worker capacity.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Martin Dewhurst</strong>, a senior partner in McKinseys London office, and <strong>Tom Latkovic</strong>, a senior partner in the Cleveland office, are McKinsey Health Institute (MHI) global leaders; <strong>Erica Coe</strong>, a partner in the Atlanta office, and <strong>Lars Hartenstein</strong> are MHI co-leaders; <strong>Anna Hextall</strong> is a consultant with MHI.</p>

}\n\u003c/style\u003e\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis is a decisive moment in the history of human health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn many respects, health is a remarkable success story. Over the past century, life expectancy has dramatically increased in most parts of the world. But the portion of life we human beings spend in moderate and poor health hasn\u0026rsquo;t changed, meaning we spend more years in poor health than at any point in history. Moreover, significant inequity continues to exist across and within countries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe can do better\u0026mdash;quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHumanity mobilized against COVID-19 at a speed and scale previously unseen. While far from perfect, our success should inspire us to challenge what we think is possible. At its best, our response to COVID-19 demonstrates that when resources and motivation coalesce, scientific breakthroughs and large-scale behavior change are possible in very short periods of time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s time to set a new, more ambitious, more relevant goal for human health\u0026mdash;a goal that galvanizes across continents, sectors, and communities to support everyone on the planet in adding years to their lives and life to their years. Humanity needs a goal that yields more time with loved ones, more accomplishments, and more time free from cognitive or physical impairment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a starting point for discussion, the McKinsey Health Institute (MHI) believes that over the next decade humanity could add as many as \u003cstrong\u003e45 billion extra years of higher-quality life\u0026mdash;roughly six years per person on average, and substantially more in some countries and populations.\u003c/strong\u003e[[Footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAchieving this objective requires us, as a society, to challenge our beliefs about health and reorient material portions of public policy and the economy. It requires embracing a modernized understanding of health, including physical, mental, social, and spiritual health[[Footnote 2]], and the full richness of factors that influence those \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/reframing-employee-health-moving-beyond-burnout-to-holistic-health\"\u003eelements of holistic health\u003c/a\u003e. It requires viewing health as an investment, not an expense. It requires scaling solutions that work, which could address 40 percent of the disease burden.[[Footnote 3]] It requires dramatically more innovation and leadership from institutions outside of the traditional healthcare industry. It requires fully empowering individuals to steward their own health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEvery institution, every leader, and every person has an important role to play.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[TableOfContents]][[SectionHeader 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eGood health underpins our ability to lead productive and enjoyable lives. Health enables social development and spurs economic growth. Year after year, experts cite social and physical components of health as two of the top three drivers of life satisfaction for individuals.[[Footnote 4]] Global healthcare spending is often over (or about) $8 trillion each year and increases faster than GDP.[[Footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the past centuries, scientific progress, innovation, greater investment, and trade and exchange across the public, private, and social sectors have led to great advancements in prolonging and improving life. Between 1800 and 2017, average global life expectancy more than doubled, from 30 years to 73 years.[[Footnote 6]] In some of the least advantaged global regions, life expectancy has increased by ten years in just the past two decades.[[Footnote 7]] Since 1900 in the United States, infant mortality has fallen by 90 percent and maternal mortality has decreased by 99 percent.[[Footnote 8]] Major breakthroughs in vaccination have enabled humanity to eradicate or suppress deadly infectious diseases such as smallpox and polio.[[Footnote 9]] Since 1990, we have seen breakthroughs in human genomics, a substantial reduction in cancer mortality, and improvements in smoking cessation.[[Footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003ch5 style=\"margin-top: 0;\"\u003eSince 1960, there has been a significant increase in average global life expectancy.\u003c/h5\u003e\n\u003ch6 style=\"margin-top: 0;\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLife expectancy\u003c/strong\u003e,\u003csup\u003e1\u003c/sup\u003e in years\u003c/h6\u003e\n[[BespokeInteractive 1]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile it\u0026rsquo;s important to recognize and learn from our progress, we must also acknowledge how much more we have to accomplish collectively.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe share of our lives we spend in poor health has not diminished over time. On average, people spend about 50 percent of their lives in less-than-good health including 12 percent in poor health.[[Footnote 11]][[Footnote 12]] The best available data suggest that this ratio has not changed much in the past 50 years. The upshot is that we spend more time in absolute terms in moderate and poor health than we have at any other point in history. The situation may be gradually worsening, particularly in high-income countries, where chronic conditions now afflict growing numbers of people for a significant portion of their lives (Exhibit 1). Literature on life satisfaction shows that having a substantial health problem\u0026mdash;defined as declining from \u0026ldquo;good health\u0026rdquo; to \u0026ldquo;poor health\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;reduces life satisfaction twice as much as losing a job or becoming widowed, divorced, or separated and five times as much as losing half of one\u0026rsquo;s income.[[Footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eNumerous known threats to human health remain insufficiently addressed. Infectious diseases still account for eight million deaths per year, and there are substantial unmet patient needs within oncology, diabetes, cardiovascular conditions, and brain disorders.[[Footnote 14]][[Footnote 15]][[Footnote 16]] The prevalence of mental health conditions has risen by 55 percent since 1990, and researchers anticipated 17 percent growth between 2020 and 2040 before COVID-19.[[Footnote 17]][[Footnote 18]][[Footnote 19]] The suicide rate in the United States has risen over the past 20 years to become the second-leading cause of death for people between the ages of ten and 34.[[Footnote 20]] Global cases of dementia are expected to triple by 2050, afflicting more than 150 million people.[[Footnote 21]] The rise in chronic, impairing lower back pain is likely linked to obesity, which has tripled globally since 1975, from 4 percent to 13 percent of the world\u0026rsquo;s population.[[Footnote 22]] There are also concerns about the potential negative effects of climate change on health, including challenges related to food security and infectious diseases. The impacts of climate change would disproportionately affect the health of vulnerable populations and people in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), which is likely to exacerbate existing inequalities.[[Footnote 23]][[Footnote 24]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHealth inequity remains a major problem, with disparities in access and outcomes persisting between and within countries and regions and across gender, wealth, and other demographic identifiers. There is an 18-year gap in average life expectancy between low- and high-income countries, and a 30-year gap between the lowest and highest life expectancy.[[Footnote 25]][[Footnote 26]] Maternal mortality rates are 50 or even 100 times higher in some low-income countries than in high-income countries.[[Footnote 27]] Childhood cancer survival rates are above 80 percent in high-income countries, but as low as 30 percent in LMICs.[[Footnote 28]] In New York City, Black non-Hispanic women are eight times more likely to die of pregnancy-related complications than White women.[[Footnote 29]] In England, the residents of London have a life expectancy three years longer than their fellow citizens in the North East.[[Footnote 30]] Globally, women\u0026rsquo;s mental and emotional health is at its lowest in 15 years and significantly below the overall population average.[[Footnote 31]] While there is some increasing awareness among healthcare stakeholders regarding sex- and gender-related needs, gaps remain. For example, women make up only one-third of cardiovascular clinical trial participants globally, and large knowledge gaps exist in gender-specific mechanisms and optimal drug doses for women in heart failure.[[Footnote 32]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eHumanity has the wealth, technology, capacity, and know-how to set and pursue a bolder aspiration for our health. MHI\u0026rsquo;s estimate of achievable impact includes \u003cem\u003elifting\u003c/em\u003e average quality of life; \u003cem\u003esquaring\u003c/em\u003e, or increasing the portion of life we spend in good health; and \u003cem\u003eextending\u003c/em\u003e life expectancy over the baseline trend (Exhibit 2).[[Footnote 33]] The gains in LMICs could be even larger than the global average.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhat leads us to conclude such a feat is possible?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, many countries across income levels have, in recent history, achieved significant gains in healthy life expectancy within a decade: 3.8 years in Bolivia, 3.0 years in Ireland, 2.6 in Oman, 6.5 years in South Africa and 4.5 years in Thailand.[[Footnote 34]] There are also countries and regions\u0026mdash;the so-called blue zones\u0026mdash;that appear to have achieved particularly high levels of longevity and stronger health in older age.[[Footnote 35]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, tremendous untapped potential exists in the systematic, equitable, and extensive application of \u003cem\u003eexisting knowledge\u003c/em\u003e. Previous research led by the McKinsey Global Institute in 2020 concluded that by applying existing and close-to-market interventions, we could eliminate about 40 percent of the current global disease burden by 2040.[[Footnote 36]] Health innovation in the visible pipeline could cut the disease burden by a further 6 to 10 percent.[[Footnote 37]][[Footnote 38]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThird, the world\u0026rsquo;s response to COVID-19 demonstrates that remarkable innovations and behavior changes can happen quickly when intense focus is combined with resources and collaboration across governments, for-profits, nonprofits, and communities. The world created not only multiple safe and effective vaccines but also numerous treatments and treatment protocols used by millions of clinicians across the world.[[Footnote 39]][[Footnote 40]] The pandemic also proved that it is possible for billions of people to rapidly modify their behavior in favorable ways (for example, safeguarding protocols, handwashing, self-administered diagnostic testing) when they are convinced it\u0026rsquo;s in their interest and are properly equipped. Even outside of the COVID-19 response, other industries (for example, technology, mobile, and automotive) have also demonstrated significant progress in improving product output, safety, and quality at the same or lower cost over a single decade.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe remainder of this article describes the shifts MHI believes society will need to make to realize the possible gains in both life expectancy and quality of life.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eHistorically, society has defined health in terms of the presence or absence of disease. Someone is deemed to be \u0026ldquo;in good health\u0026rdquo; if disease has no impact on their life expectancy or physical function. To add up to 45 billion years of higher-quality life, MHI proposes that we embrace a broader definition of health that better aligns with individual aspirations and the latest scientific research. The World Health Organization (WHO) proposed just such a broad definition of health, with a greater emphasis on well-being, back in 1948: health is a \u0026ldquo;state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity.\u0026rdquo; The subcomponents of spiritual health[[Footnote 41]] have also been recognized as relevant to health for decades.[[Footnote 42]] MHI uses the term \u0026ldquo;spiritual\u0026rdquo; because it is the most common way for other healthcare institutions and leaders to refer to these concepts. Strong spiritual health does not necessarily imply the adoption of religious beliefs. Unfortunately, a broad vision of health has not taken hold. MHI proposes that society fully embrace the proposed foundation and act on it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMHI proposes an understanding of health with the following characteristics:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHolistic. \u003c/strong\u003eIt recognizes the relevance and interdependencies of physical, mental, social, and spiritual dimensions.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUses a positive frame. \u003c/strong\u003eThe objective on each dimension is \u003cem\u003eoptimal\u003c/em\u003e health given an individual\u0026rsquo;s physiological capacity, not simply the absence of disease.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAnchored in function. \u003c/strong\u003eHealth is relevant only to the extent it enables people to live fully\u0026mdash;to build relationships, work or volunteer, and contribute to society while also enjoying pursuits.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAffected by a multitude of influences. \u003c/strong\u003eThis understanding of health recognizes the vast set of factors that affect health, including personal attributes, personal behaviors, interventions, and environmental attributes.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eObjective. \u003c/strong\u003eIt is measurable across time, geographies, health systems, and cultures.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[BespokeInteractive 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eStrong anecdotal and empirical evidence suggests that these four health dimensions collectively contribute to both longevity and quality of life. Individuals often suffer harm when their health fails along even one of these dimensions. For example, global data indicate that severe mental health disorders can reduce life expectancy anywhere from 10 to 25 years.[[Footnote 52]] On the social health dimension, loneliness and social isolation are associated with higher risks of heart attack and strokes.[[Footnote 53]] In fact, research shows that loneliness and social isolation can be as damaging to an individual\u0026rsquo;s health as smoking 15 cigarettes per day,[[Footnote 54]] which is especially concerning when we note that up to 29 percent of elderly people report feeling lonely.[[Footnote 55]] A lack of social connections has been associated with an increase in inflammation at the same magnitude as physical inactivity in adolescence, and in old age, the effect of social isolation on hypertension exceeded that of clinical risk factors such as diabetes.[[Footnote 56]] On a more hopeful note, for older American adults, greater purpose in life has been linked with a lower risk of stroke.[[Footnote 57]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA more complete understanding of human health also includes acknowledging the extensive set of factors that affect it. These \u003cstrong\u003einfluencing factors\u003c/strong\u003e fall into four groups: personal attributes, personal behaviors, environmental attributes, and interventions. Personal behaviors refer to individual actions such as sleep, diet, exercise, and adherence to treatment regimens. Personal attributes are individual characteristics such as genetics, education, and relationships that typically cannot be modified, at least in the short term. Environmental attributes are factors that shape the health of all individuals within a given context and include the context\u0026rsquo;s political and economic system as well as global threats such as climate change. Interventions refer to deliberate actions intended to bring about change, such as clinical interventions, financial support, or incentives.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eOur research suggests that adding up to 45 billion years of higher-quality life would require at least six material shifts in societal mindsets and actions (Exhibit 3). These shifts are highly interdependent and mutually reinforcing, and adopting them would represent a material reorientation of public policy and the economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch3\u003eShift 1. Invest more, disproportionately on prevention and promoting optimal health\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlocking up to 45 billion years of higher-quality life will require individuals, governments, and private institutions to invest more financial and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/human-capital-at-work-the-value-of-experience\"\u003ehuman capital\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as a percentage of GDP to improve health. Greater investment in health-related interventions is justified in areas traditionally considered part of the healthcare system and in other parts of the economy\u0026mdash;such as education, nutrition and agriculture, consumer products, financial services, and technology\u0026mdash;that have the potential to improve health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe case for greater investment in health is economically sound and responsive to citizen and consumer preferences. McKinsey Global Institute\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003ePrioritizing health\u003c/em\u003e report estimates that improving the health of the global population by effectively scaling known interventions could generate an ROI of two to four times, even when only considering economic benefits. Individuals consistently place a high priority on improving health.[[Footnote 58]] Year after year, experts cite social and physical elements of health as two of the top three drivers of life satisfaction for individuals.[[Footnote 59]] A significant positive correlation exists between greater investment in health and improvements in living standards and wealth across countries and time. MHI believes a causal link exists. High-income countries do not appear to have reached a point of diminishing returns.[[Footnote 60]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMHI further proposes disproportionately investing in disease prevention and health promotion in addition to treatment to help people truly thrive. Promotion is defined here as actions that help individuals achieve and sustain the best possible physical, mental, social, and spiritual health given their intrinsic biological capacity.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 5]]\n\u003cspan class=\"mhi--video\"\u003e[[FullBleedPhoto 1]]\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCurrently, health spending is heavily tilted toward curative care. OECD countries spend just 2.8 percent of their health budgets on organized prevention programs such as vaccinations, disease screenings, and health education.[[Footnote 61]][[Footnote 62]] Low-income economies spend ten times as much (as a proportion of budget) as OECD countries do on preventative measures, which amounts to 20 to 35 percent of these low-income economies\u0026rsquo; healthcare budgets.[[Footnote 63]] At the moment, most investment and innovation in achieving optimal health come from the private sector. The global wellness market, for example, is valued at $1.5 trillion, roughly four times the size of what governments and NGOs spend globally on preventive care and health promotion.[[Footnote 64]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, MHI proposes disproportionately investing in under-resourced populations as both a moral imperative and a good financial decision. Improving the health of populations with historically reduced access to care or worse-than-average health outcomes can give societies a potent economic boost. Better health is associated with improved labor productivity and higher income. For example, 11 percent of economic growth in LMICs from 1970 to 2000 resulted from reduced rates of adult mortality.[[Footnote 65]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a first step to realizing this shift, governments might consider conducting a \u0026ldquo;health opportunity assessment\u0026rdquo; across all government agencies, including those outside of healthcare (for example, environment, education, treasury, trade, agriculture, housing, and infrastructure) to understand the most critical links to health and to unearth potential high-ROI investments for consideration, including the net effect of laws, regulations, and government activity on private sector activity.[[Footnote 66]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eShift 2. Improve measurement of a modernized understanding of health with better data\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAttaining the aspiration requires improving global standards and systems to measure a modernized understanding of health, collecting significantly more comparative data on each element and dramatically increasing transparency.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe rationale is straightforward: measurement is foundational to improvement. Measurement helps us understand what works and what doesn\u0026rsquo;t so we can allocate resources effectively. Conversely, weak (or nonexistent) measurement leads to waste and prevents us from investing more in what might be promising innovation. Overly generalized measurements are also ineffective; for example, the absence of a diagnostic framework for autism specifically for women leads to under-diagnosis.[[Footnote 67]][[Footnote 68]] It\u0026rsquo;s clear that researchers need subgroup-specific data collection and measurement initiatives.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eMHI estimates that fewer than 5 percent of factors that influence and measure a modern understanding of health are defined consistently (or at all), captured systematically and made broadly available as data. Most elements of a modern definition of health have very modest, if any, reliable measurement standards or data, including social and spiritual health and large categories of influencing factors such as the role of nutrition, employment, housing, and sleep. An estimated 75 percent of studies related to health can be classified as having primary endpoints that measure physical health, while just 12 percent address mental health, 6 percent address social health, and 1 percent examine spiritual health.[[Footnote 69]] Most countries have very limited or no data regarding mental health, and data that are comparable across regions are lacking. For example, more than 100 countries have no data about mental health conditions among adolescents.[[Footnote 70]] And of the 23 mental-health indicators measured by OECD, only two\u0026mdash;life satisfaction and death by suicide\u0026mdash;were available in more than 90 percent of OECD countries.[[Footnote 71]] Finally, there is only a modest attempt to define or consistently measure the extent to which individuals have achieved optimal possible health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven physical health measurements, the area with the best standards and data, offer considerable room for improvement. High-income countries capture primarily disease prevalence and select health interventions (for example, prescriptions, office visits, and procedures). Few data are systematically captured or available with respect to function itself or health status such as mobility, toxin levels, pain, and sexual function. Challenges in lower-income countries are more fundamental and include undigitized patient records, siloed reporting due to unintegrated care, and lack of access to diagnostic technologies.[[Footnote 72]][[Footnote 73]] Positive examples, such as India, have shown how LMIC economies can still build robust nationwide health registries over time.[[Footnote 74]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn example of the tangible downside associated with weak measurement is the challenge high-income countries face in subjecting nonpharmaceutical interventions to rigorous empirical analysis. Since 2007, only 11 percent of food-related health claims\u0026mdash;a large component of the nonpharmaceutical-intervention category\u0026mdash;have met the EU criteria for robust scientific evidence.[[Footnote 75]][[Footnote 76]][[Footnote 77]] Of the estimated 20,000 mental-health apps available for download on personal computers and smartphones, five have been formally vetted and approved by the US Food and Drug Administration.[[Footnote 78]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eShift 3. Scale what works\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003ePrioritizing health\u003c/em\u003e report estimates that by applying existing and proven interventions, the global disease burden could be reduced by about 40 percent (Exhibit 4).[[Footnote 79]] Scaling known interventions could reduce child mortality by 65 percent and help a typical 65-year-old to be as healthy as a typical 55-year-old today. These numbers only account for improvements in physical and, to some extent, mental health. The potential for improved outcomes when health is considered more broadly is even greater. For high-income countries, most of the potential is in addressing diabetes, cancer, and cardiovascular disease. Low-income countries would benefit from more investment in known, basic health infrastructure.[[Footnote 80]] Furthermore, scaling up largely preventative solutions and targeting infectious diseases and nutritional disorders as well as maternal, neonatal, and child health are high-potential improvements.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003cp\u003ePast experience shows that scaling existing technologies can be very challenging\u0026mdash;the global rollout of hepatitis B vaccines took more than 17 years, and survival after a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes in some LMICs is as low as one year, often due to the unaffordability of insulin.[[Footnote 81]][[Footnote 82]][[Footnote 83]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo scale what works, societies need awareness and a commitment from people, governments, payers (including employers), and healthcare providers to adapt. Each group has an opportunity to overcome myopia and biases and establish strategies, policies, and incentives to increase the application of known solutions with high ROI. In many cases, such adaptation also requires greater net investment, as previously stated.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother key to scaling what works is applying proven interventions across contexts, including countries and populations. Literature extensively describes differences in health outcomes for the same diseases by health provider, even within the same geography.[[Footnote 84]][[Footnote 85]][[Footnote 86]][[Footnote 87]] At their worst, healthcare systems and especially providers can be overly focused on their own systems. For example, the Aravind Eye Care System in southern India developed a successful and efficient system for delivering high-quality and low-cost cataract surgery.[[Footnote 88]] Despite the potential for meaningful application in other parts of the world, including high-income countries, this system remains primarily anchored in the local context.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eShift 4. Innovate more, and more quickly\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore innovation in all forms will be required, including in such areas as business models, government policies, incentive schemes, pharmaceuticals, medical devices, clinical standards, mobile apps, medical products, process improvements, and novel applications of existing technologies such as artificial intelligence. Increasing innovation will require more foundational research, better collaboration to break through silos, and quicker and more effective nurturing and scaling of the most promising concepts.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 6]]\n\u003cp\u003eInnovation, along with greater investment in health, has been the driving force behind most advances in health. Once scientists identified the link between diabetes and insulin production in the pancreas a century ago, a continuous chain of discovery and commercialization has transformed the lives of diabetes patients.[[Footnote 89]] Cancer mortality in the United States fell 32 percent from 1991 to 2019,[[Footnote 90]] in part due to new surgical techniques, detection tools, and targeted therapies.[[Footnote 91]] The exceptional pace of development and deployment of vaccines for COVID-19 is illustrative of the opportunity to drastically accelerate progress in public health when societal will, incentives, and resources are aligned. COVID-19 vaccines progressed from discovery to global distribution of the finished product in less than 12 months. Vaccine development is a high-risk process that traditionally takes more than a decade to complete. Prior to COVID-19, the fastest vaccine ever developed\u0026mdash;for mumps in 1967\u0026mdash;took four years from discovery to market launch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYet there are many areas where innovation has not occurred as hoped, often in the context of market failures. Despite the urgent threat of antimicrobial resistance (AMR), innovation in new antibiotics and alternatives has been weak, due in part to lack of incentives to invest in research and development.[[Footnote 92]][[Footnote 93]] The antibiotic pipeline is substantially weaker than those for other therapeutic areas, such as treatment for cancer. One comparison: between 2017 and 2020, 1,751 immuno-oncology drugs were in preclinical and research phase, and 45 received approval. In the same period, just 292 antibiotics were in preclinical and research phase, and 11 received approval.[[Footnote 94]][[Footnote 95]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to even more innovation from the life sciences industry, humanity would benefit from substantially more innovation from other industries and domains, especially via the application of emerging technologies[[Footnote 96]] such as applied artificial intelligence, next-generation computing, and distributed computing. In addition, society has yet to realize the full potential of digital health innovation to improve health outcomes. Good momentum for catalyzing new or greater innovation exists, especially among venture- and private-equity-backed companies. Venture capital investments in digital health reached an all-time high of $29 billion in 2021, nearly doubling 2020\u0026rsquo;s investments.[[Footnote 97]] Promising concepts include wearables (for example, activity tracking, cardiac anomaly detection, patches for blood sugar monitoring, physiotherapy for pain relief with body-posture detection), telesurgery, and AI-enabled diagnostics. Telemedicine exploded worldwide in 2020 due to COVID-19; in the United States, it grew by 3,800 percent in 2020, and some consumers continue to indicate a preference for it.[[Footnote 98]][[Footnote 99]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, capturing the full potential impact from innovation will require us to rethink the way we innovate. We need to create an ecosystem of innovation by looking at all processes and influencing factors and engaging all stakeholders who affect a desired health outcome. This kind of innovation allows for better implementation mechanisms, end-to-end coordination, and collaboration to effectively and efficiently support sustainable behavior change and improve patient pathways. One such example is the Stop TB Partnership, which aims to end tuberculosis worldwide by 2030.[[Footnote 100]] The organization defined the optimal end-to-end care flow for tuberculosis, identified key interventions, and mapped stakeholders against each. It then aligned all contributors on the same data standards and coordinated their efforts, which resulted in an ecosystem that is both effective and scalable. Another example of an effective ecosystem can be found in Amsterdam, where multiple city departments (beyond the health department) work together in a coalition to achieve highly ambitious health and well-being targets.[[Footnote 101]][[Footnote 102]][[Footnote 103]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eImpactful innovation requires integrated, purposeful action across governments and the private sector. Governments might consider how to adapt investments, budgets, regulations and regular processes, intellectual property schemes, reimbursement principles, and laws to better catalyze innovation in areas with the greatest societal needs. Government action may be particularly relevant where the risk of market failure is high. Individuals and private payers, including insurers and employers, might consider how to adapt their consumption patterns and reimbursement policies to seek and reward promising innovations. Finally, greater innovation requires businesses from outside the healthcare sector to view health as an emerging or core market to enter, disrupt, and pursue.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eShift 5. Unleash the full potential of all industries\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAchieving the set aspiration requires institutions outside of the traditional healthcare industry to pursue health-related business opportunities much more aggressively, better enable and empower their employees, and better define and honor health-related environmental, social, and governance (ESG) commitments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHealth is deeply relevant to every business in the world, at minimum because employers affect the health of their employees, and the health of employees affects their performance. Sixty-eight percent of companies say employee well-being and mental health is a top strategic priority.[[Footnote 104]] Poor employee health costs about $3.5 trillion annually.[[Footnote 105]] In the United Kingdom, 17.9 million working days were lost to mental-health illnesses from 2019 to 2020, which was more than half of the total working days lost to poor health.[[Footnote 106]] For many businesses, health is also part of their ESG commitments. Yet, while 66 percent of Fortune 500 companies publish sustainability reports, only about 4 percent published health impact reports prior to COVID-19.[[Footnote 107]] Fewer have developed or implemented systemic policies to improve employee health.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 7]]\n\u003cp\u003eEven more critically, MHI estimates that 40 to 45 percent of companies in the S\u0026amp;P 500 that are not considered part of the healthcare industry deliver products or services that directly affect the health of individuals (Exhibit 5), sometimes favorably and sometimes unfavorably. Industries with highly health-relevant products or services include food and nutrition, consumer products, social media, transportation, gaming, travel, consumer financial services, non-health-related insurance, housing, and heating and cooling systems. Companies in these industries have an opportunity to leverage their relevance much more aggressively to explore even more significant, more disruptive entry into healthcare in both traditional and emerging domains. In some cases, companies face an imperative to understand and mitigate the potentially unfavorable effect of their products or services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMoreover, companies that don\u0026rsquo;t have a direct or strong link to health, still have the opportunity to empower employees to improve their health and honor health-related environmental, social and government commitments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eShift 6. Empower individuals to steward their own health\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo unlock up to 45 billion years of higher-quality life, individuals need to be empowered as the primary stewards of their own health and their loved ones\u0026rsquo; health. Individual behaviors are the single biggest driver of an individual\u0026rsquo;s health. Multiple studies have shown that modifiable behaviors\u0026mdash;including diet, activity levels, sleep, adherence to medication, and tobacco use\u0026mdash;contribute to as much as 60 percent of deaths worldwide.[[Footnote 108]] Individual mindsets and behaviors are likely even more relevant when considered through the lens of a modernized, holistic understanding of health that also includes the role of mental, social, and spiritual functioning. Almost every aspect of our lives and most of our choices affect our health.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 7]]\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers across cultures and countries are increasingly demanding more empowerment. Their expectations are shaped by experiences of speed, convenience, personalization, and access to information from other industries, and they expect the same with respect to their health. Trust in institutions is declining in many regions, increasing the felt need of many individuals to be more self-directed.[[Footnote 109]] Finally, in many parts of the world, healthcare remains largely self-funded, which puts an even greater onus on the individual.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecent experience shows that massive changes of behavior are possible. Billions of people significantly changed their daily actions, such as wearing face masks and social distancing, to protect themselves and their families during the COVID-19 pandemic. Insights from behavioral economics also show how to motivate and empower individuals so they are most likely to make decisions that are in their own best interest. Nudging\u0026mdash;which behavioral science defines as a means of altering people\u0026rsquo;s behavior without restricting their choices or changing their economic incentives\u0026mdash;can influence the behavior and decision making of individuals and groups. For example, nudging has been shown to improve hand hygiene among healthcare workers to decrease the number of healthcare-associated infections.[[Footnote 110]] In addition to purposeful nudging, social networks and their associated culture, mindsets, and behaviors are highly correlated with individuals\u0026rsquo; health-relevant decisions and behaviors. Empowering individuals will require action from the government, more innovation, and adaptation from traditional healthcare stakeholders. Governments can consider how they might adapt laws, regulations, incentives, and government-operated healthcare services to better empower people. Governments might also consider how to adapt (or create) environments, structures, or systems to make it easier for consumers to make healthy choices.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eEmpowering individuals will require substantially more technology-based innovation, including mobile or remote access that optimizes exercise, sleep, caloric intake, posture, and the like. Innovation that empowers individuals is exploding across low-, middle-, and high-income countries. In rural India, for example, smartphones enable individuals to have greater access to healthcare providers.[[Footnote 111]] Approximately 200 million Chinese consumers have used Ping An\u0026rsquo;s Good Doctor mobile platform to receive consultation, referrals, and appointments.[[Footnote 112]] In 2019, 21 percent of Americans reported using smart watches or fitness trackers.[[Footnote 113]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, healthcare stakeholders, especially provider institutions and clinicians, might consider how to embrace many patients\u0026rsquo; desire to be self-directed. Providers have an opportunity to operate more as coaches who help patients define and execute a coauthored care plan. Providers also have an opportunity to embrace many of the technology-based solutions emerging outside the traditional healthcare industry cited above.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eDramatically improving our health requires an ecosystem approach \u0026ndash; exchanging ideas, aligning around standards, working across multiple stakeholder silos. It will require unprecedented collaboration to shift society\u0026rsquo;s mindsets and actions enough to realize possible gains in life expectancy and quality of life.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey Health Institute is an enduring, non-profit-generating global entity within McKinsey that strives to catalyze actions across continents, sectors, and communities to extend and improve lives. MHI is committed to contributing to this collective ecosystem. MHI is fostering a strong network of organizations committed to this aspiration through a range of collaboration types \u0026ndash; convening and enabling leaders, advancing research, creating and promoting open-access data assets, and stimulating innovation. MHI is sharing resources, innovations, data, and findings in the public domain so others can replicate what proves effective and looks to its ecosystem partners to commit to the same.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMHI welcomes connection with committed organizations interested in building out this ecosystem together. MHI is actively seeking opportunities to collaborate across its identified six shifts as well as seven initial key focus areas: brain health, healthy living, infectious diseases, equity and health, sustainability and health, healthy aging, and healthcare-worker capacity.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Report"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":true},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":{"name":"McKinsey Health Institute","displayName":"McKinsey Health Institute","title":{"value":"McKinsey Health Institute"},"relatedlinks":{"url":"/mhi/overview"},"landinglinks":{"jsonValue":{"value":[]}}}},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-03-24T21:01:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCalculated in a scenario-based simulation sizing three effects: increase of life expectancy (\u0026ldquo;extending\u0026rdquo;), decrease of lifetime spent in poor health, and decrease of lifetime in moderate rather than good health (\u0026ldquo;lifting\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;squaring the curve\"). countries and populations is both the right thing to do and a requirement to reach the aspiration. MHI acknowledges that this is an arena where more research and work could be critical, especially to achieve impact at scale. Moreover, equity priorities will vary considerably across communities based on contexts and cultures. That said, research suggests a few foundational actions are needed. The first is to acknowledge and measure inequity to encourage accountability, motivate action, and better understand root causes of poor health. The second is for governments, businesses, and social institutions to be even more intentional in creating focused strategies to address inequities. Finally, MHI believes a focus on equity can and should be considered and integrated into all other actions to improve health, both to uncover potential opportunities to reduce inequity and to mitigate the risk of unintentionally exacerbating it."}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Addressing health inequity"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Gray"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}}]},"globalsidebar":{"results":[]},"video":{"results":[]},"scrollycontainer":{"results":[]},"bespokeinteractive":{"results":[{"id":"84CD62E0EC0B4F5EB0534D13CC85D0CC","template":{"name":"BespokeInteractive"},"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Extra large full width"},"value":{"value":"extra-large-full-width"}}},"showDividerLine":{"boolValue":false},"bespokeInteractiveID":{"value":"mhi_interactive_test/apps/life-expectancy-heatmap"},"header":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"displayNumber":{"value":""},"eyebrow":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"accessibilityDescription":{"value":"Interactive map visualization illustrating life expectancy across countries in the world over time, from 1960 to 2017.
